duck: A coming together; sexual intercourse; copulation.
A coming together; sexual intercourse; copulation.

wiki.text:
, the most common human sex position,<ref name="Roberts"></ref><ref
name="Weiten, 2008"></ref> depicted by Édouard-Henri Avril.]] 'Sexual
intercourse', or 'copulation' or 'coitus', is the insertion and thrusting of a
male's penis into a female's vagina for the purposes of sexual pleasure or reproduction.<!--
NOTE: As shown, the terms "copulation" and "coitus" are being defined in the
first sentence as well, and these two alternative terms for sexual intercourse,
especially coitus, usually mean penile-vaginal intercourse, as supported by
sources (including those used to discuss the topic in the "Etymology and
definitions" section below).--><ref name="Starr"></ref><ref
name="Collins"></ref><ref name="Kar"></ref><ref
name="health.discovery.com"></ref> Other forms of penetrative sexual intercourse
include anal sex, oral sex, fingering, and use of a strap-on dildo.<ref
name="Kar"/><ref name=health.discovery.com/><ref>The Gender of Sexuality:
Exploring Sexual Possibilities; Page 76 – Virginia Rutter, Pepper Schwartz –
2011</ref>

Sexual intercourse commonly contributes to human bonding, usually being used
solely for pleasure and often leading to stronger emotional bonds,<ref
name="Diamond"></ref> and there are a variety of views concerning what
constitutes sexual intercourse or other sexual activity.<ref
name="Lerner">{{cite book | title = Handbook of Adolescent Psychology |
publisher = John Wiley & Sons | year = 2004 | pages = 193–196 | accessdate =
April 29, 2013 |isbn = 0471690449| url = http://books.google.com/books?id=_wXas-
Y1HyAYC&pg=PA193&dq=When+researchers+use+the+term+sex,+they+nearly+always+mean+-
sexual+intercourse+--+more+specfically,+penile-
vaginal+intercourse.&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ggR_Ua7BK4ODqgGmxID4BQ&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA#v=one-
page&q=When%20researchers%20use%20the%20term%20sex%2C%20they%20nearly%20always%-
20mean%20sexual%20intercourse%20--%20more%20specfically%2C%20penile-
vaginal%20intercourse.&f=false|quote=When researchers use the term sex, they
nearly always mean sexual intercourse – more specifically, penile-vaginal
intercourse... The widespread, unquestioned equation of penile-vaginal
intercourse with sex reflects a failure to examine systematically 'whether the
respondent's understanding of the question matches what the researcher had in
mind.'| author = Richard M. Lerner, Laurence Steinberg}}</ref><ref
name="Randall"></ref><ref name="Carpenter">See [http://books.google.com/books?i-
d=6qNCeI2AcY4C&pg=PT11&lpg=PT11&dq=Many+studies,+moreover,+seemed+uncritically+-
to+lump+nonvirgin+teens+(so+designated+if+they'd+had+vaginal+sex)&source=bl&ots-
=-
giTNZ0Jtq&sig=J6YapNhv6SAukvLSFYJ6wPFlNrA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=VElGUKSLL6m62wXZ5oHQDA&-
ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Many%20studies%2C%20moreover%2C%20seemed%20uncritic-
ally%20to%20lump%20nonvirgin%20teens%20(so%20designated%20if%20they'd%20had%20v-
aginal%20sex)&f=false here] and [http://books.google.com/books?id=pXXZn_qSoDoC&-
pg=PA48&dq=In+contrast+to+lesbigay+men+and+women,+most+of+whom+claimed+that+ora-
l+and+anal+sex+would+result+in+virginity+loss+for+any+combination+of+partners,+-
the+majority+of+heterosexuals+I+spoke+with+placed+oral+sex+between+men+and+wome-
n+squarely+in+the+category+of+foreplay---&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yGWtUKGFN4mo2gXN-
4HYBQ&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=In%20contrast%20to%20lesbigay%20men%20and%20w-
omen%2C%20most%20of%20whom%20claimed%20that%20oral%20and%20anal%20sex%20would%2-
0result%20in%20virginity%20loss%20for%20any%20combination%20of%20partners%2C%20-
the%20majority%20of%20heterosexuals%20I%20spoke%20with%20placed%20oral%20sex%20-
between%20men%20and%20women%20squarely%20in%20the%20category%20of%20foreplay---
&f=false pages 47-49] for views on what constitutes virginity loss and therefore
sexual activity; source discusses how gay and lesbian individuals define
virginity loss, and how the majority of researchers and heterosexuals define
virginity loss/"technical virginity" by whether or not a person has engaged in
vaginal sex. </ref> For example, non-penetrative sex (such as non-penetrative
cunnilingus) has been referred to as "outercourse",<ref name="Kamen"></ref><ref
name="Durham"></ref> but may also be among the sexual acts contributing to human
bonding and considered sexual intercourse. The term sex, often a shorthand for
sexual intercourse, can mean any form of sexual activity.<ref
name=health.discovery.com/><ref name="Randall"/><ref name="WHO, Sex"></ref><ref
name="www.ejhs.org"></ref> Because individuals can be at risk of contracting
sexually transmitted infections during these activities,<ref
name="Who"></ref><ref name="CDC"> Also see
[http://www.cdc.gov/std/stats08/2008survFactSheet.PDF Fact Sheet]</ref> though
the transmission risk is significantly reduced during non-penetrative sex,<ref
name="Durham"/><ref name="aids.gov"></ref> safe sex practices are advised.<ref
name="Who"/>

In human societies, some jurisdictions have placed various restrictive laws
against certain sexual activities, such as sex with minors, incest, extramarital
sex, position-of-trust sex, prostitution, sodomy, public lewdness, rape, and
zoophilia. Religious beliefs can play a role in decisions about sex, or its
purpose, as well; for example, beliefs about what sexual acts constitute
virginity loss or the decision to make a virginity pledge.<ref
name="Consent"></ref><ref name="Intimate"></ref><ref>{{cite
journal|author=Bersamin MM, Walker S, Waiters ED, Fisher DA, Grube
JW|title=Promising to wait: virginity pledges and adolescent sexual
behavior|journal=J Adolesc Health|volume=36|issue=5|pages=428–36|year=2005|mont-
h=May|pmid=15837347|pmc=1949026 |doi=10.1016/j.jadohealth.2004.09.016|url=http:-
//linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1054-139X(05)00108-4}}</ref> Some
sections of Christianity commonly view sexual activity between a married couple
for the purpose of reproduction as holy, while other sections may not.<ref
name=Akin>Daniel L. Akin. God on Sex: The Creator's Ideas About Love, Intimacy,
and Marriage. (2003). B&H Publishing Group. ISBN 0-8054-2596-9</ref> Modern
Judaism and Islam view sexual intercourse between husband and wife as a
spiritual and edifying action. Hinduism and Buddhism views on sexuality have
differing interpretations.

Sexual intercourse between non-human animals is more often termed copulation;
for most non-human mammals, mating and copulation occur at the point of estrus
(the most fertile period of time in the female's reproductive cycle), which
increases the chances of successful impregnation.<ref name="Kent"></ref><ref
name="Thorpe"></ref> However, bonobos,<ref name=FransDeWaal/> dolphins,<ref
name="Bailey"></ref> and chimpanzees are known to engage in sexual intercourse
even when the female is not in estrus, and to engage in sex acts with same-sex
partners.<ref name="Bailey"/><ref name="Bagemihl">Bruce Bagemihl, Biological
Exuberance: Animal Homosexuality and Natural Diversity (St. Martin's Press,
1999). ISBN 0-312-19239-8</ref> Like humans engaging in sexual activity
primarily for pleasure,<ref name="Diamond"/> this behavior in the aforementioned
animals is also presumed to be for pleasure,<ref name="Balcombe">Balcombe, J.
Pleasurable Kingdom: Animals and the Nature of Feeling Good. Macmillan, New
York, 2007. 360 pp. ISBN 1-4039-8602-9 [http://books.google.com/books?id=MyKox3-
YXI1kC&lpg=PR7&ots=XfYY7mTGUH&dq=Jonathan%20Balcombe's%20Pleasurable%20Kingdom&-
pg=PA106#v=onepage&q=Jonathan%20Balcombe's%20Pleasurable%20Kingdom&f=false]</re-
f> and a contributing factor to strengthening their social bonds.<ref
name="Diamond"/>
